column1: > 04:00|"just past four in the morning"|"I wake with a start
column2: staring into the darkness
column3: fumbling for my phone. It’s just past four in the morning. I text Carolyn. Anything?"|"The President Is Missing"|"Bill Clinton"

column1: 00:00|midnight|"Five days before the election
column2: while blowing off steam with her two closest aides over a bottle of wine at midnight
column3: Carolyn made a derogatory comment about her opponent
column4: who’d just released an ad viciously attacking Carolyn’s husband
column5: a noted trial lawyer at the time. Her comment was caught on a live mike. Nobody knows who picked it up or how. Carolyn thought she was alone with her two aides in a closed restaurant."|"The President Is Missing"|"Bill Clinton"

column1: 11:00|"eleven in the morning"|"She sits on a stool fronting the window at a ledge intended for single customers
column2: looking out over the street
column3: massive vehicles lined up at a traffic light
column4: scrolling advertisements on billboards for various beers and fast food and “auto loans” and clothing stores and movies. The streets are crowded with people. The restaurant is not; it is just now eleven in the morning
column7: has not yet begun. The menu offers almost nothing she could stomach. She orders a soft drink and soup and waits."|"The President Is Missing"|"Bill Clinton"

column1: ap 09:00|9|"Then
column2: in a “down” column on the crossword puzzle
column3: he writes: Y O U H A V E I D

column1: I have it

column3: If it rains
column4: meet at 9?

column1: He writes
column2: I T W O N T"|"The President Is Missing"|"Bill Clinton"

column1: 13:30|"1:30 p.m."|"It is 1:30 p.m. in the Situation Room
column2: cool and soundproof and windowless."|"The President Is Missing"|"Bill Clinton"
back in the Oval Office
column3: I say into the phone
column4: “Mrs. Kopecky
column5: your son was a hero. We honor his service to this country. I’m praying for you and your family.”"|"The President Is Missing"|"Bill Clinton"

column1: ap 03:10|"Ten after three"|"Ten after three in the Oval Office
column2: with Danny Akers and Jenny Brickman
column3: my political adviser."|"The President Is Missing"|"Bill Clinton"

column1: ap 05:00|"five o’clock"|"I return to the Oval Office with Carolyn as the clock slowly
column2: agonizingly approaches five. We are silent. A lot of working men and women look forward to five o’clock on Friday because it signals the end of the work week
column3: some much-needed relaxation and time with family."|"The President Is Missing"|"Bill Clinton"

column1: > 12:00|"just after noon"|"It was last Monday
column2: just after noon
column3: when I received the phone call on my personal cell. Carolyn and I were grabbing turkey sandwiches in the kitchen. We already knew we were facing an imminent threat. We didn’t understand the scope or magnitude of it. We had no idea how to stop it. Our mission in Algeria had already failed in spectacular fashion for all the world to see. Suliman Cindoruk remained on the loose. My entire national security team had been subpoenaed to testify the following day
column4: Tuesday
column5: before the House Select Committee."|"The President Is Missing"|"Bill Clinton"

column1: 17:00|"Five p.m."|"But when I put down my sandwich and answered that call in the kitchen
column2: everything changed. The dynamic was completely upended. For the first time
column3: I had the tiniest sliver of hope. But I was also more scared than ever.

column1: “Five p.m. Eastern time
column2: Friday
column3: May the eleventh
column4: ” I was told.

column1: So as the time approaches five o’clock on Friday
column2: May 11
column3: I am no longer thinking about the seven innocent children in the Republic of Yemen who are dead under a pile of ash and rubble based on a decision I made."|"The President Is Missing"|"Bill Clinton"

column1: ap 04:00|"four o’clock"|"I spin back to my four o’clock and see a man coming around the driver’s side of the van

column3: a weapon up at shoulder level. I pull the trigger once
column4: twice

column9: crouched low in the dark while he’s standing by light."|"The President Is Missing"|"Bill Clinton"

ap 09:00|nine|"Davis
column2: his hands at nine and three on the wheel
column3: whips his right hand over to nine
column4: his left to three
column5: and spins the car into an evasive J-turn. I plow into Jacobson as the rear fishtails to the right again
column6: the car now profiled in the path of the oncoming truck
column7: turned sideways in the lane at the moment of impact."|"The President Is Missing"|"Bill Clinton"

column1: > 22:00|"past ten o’clock in the evening"|"The house before us is a stucco-and-brick Victorian with a manicured lawn
column2: a driveway leading up to a two-car garage
column3: and a lamp that lights the walkway to the front porch—the only light that appears to be on past ten o’clock in the evening. The stucco is painted a soft blue
column4: the origin of the nickname the Blue House."|"The President Is Missing"|"Bill Clinton"

column1: 01:03|"1:03 a.m."|"She reaches for her phone on the nightstand and checks the time: 1:03 a.m."|"The President Is Missing"|"Bill Clinton"
< 12:00|"before noon"|"They are sleeping now
column2: all of them
column3: the last of them retiring only an hour ago. None of them will be up before noon. None of them will be of any use today."|"The President Is Missing"|"Bill Clinton"

column1: 03:45|"3:45 in the morning"|"“Mr. President
column2: it’s Dr. Lane.” Her hand on my shoulder. Her face coming between me and the light. “We performed a platelet transfusion. You’re doing well. It’s 3:45 in the morning
column3: Saturday morning. You’ve been out for a little over four hours.”"|"The President Is Missing"|"Bill Clinton"

column1: ap 02:07|02:07|"Everything is dark. The time stamp in the corner of the screen shows 02:07—just past two in the morning
column2: about two hours ago."|"The President Is Missing"|"Bill Clinton"

column1: > 02:00|"just past two in the morning"|"Everything is dark. The time stamp in the corner of the screen shows 02:07—just past two in the morning

column1: < 00:00|"near midnight"|"Finally we have the chance. Since we first met at the stadium
column2: what with dodging bullets and escaping from car ambushes and my collapsing near midnight
column3: we haven’t had the chance to lock this down."|"The President Is Missing"|"Bill Clinton"

column1: 06:52|"6:52 a.m."|"Saturday morning
column2: 6:52 a.m. The limousine is parked on 13th Street Northwest by the curb."|"The President Is Missing"|"Bill Clinton"

column1: 07:00|"7:00 a.m."|"Her cover is airtight: every Saturday morning at 7:00 a.m.
column2: she and her husband have a standing reservation for omelets just around the corner on G Street Northwest at Blake’s Café. They have a table ready for her
column3: and by now her order is assumed—egg whites with feta cheese and tomatoes
column4: extra-crispy hash browns."|"The President Is Missing"|"Bill Clinton"

column1: ap 06:56|6:56|"Next to her
column2: filling in for her husband as a breakfast partner: her chief of staff
column3: Peter Evian. He holds out his phone
column4: showing her the time: 6:56."|"The President Is Missing"|"Bill Clinton"

column1: 12:00|midday|"Noya Baram and I stand on the dock looking at the lake
column2: the midday sun gaining ground in the sky
column3: its beams reflecting off the shimmering water
column4: the serenity and beauty of the scene grotesquely contrasted with the feeling of impending doom taking up residence in my gut. Not since Kennedy stared down Khrushchev over the missiles in Cuba has our nation been this close to world war."|"The President Is Missing"|"Bill Clinton"

column1: > 14:00|"just past 2:00 p.m."|"“There’s only one problem right now
column2: Carrie. Have you heard? It’s the one that might bring our country to its knees any minute now. We have”—I look at my watch; it’s just past 2:00 p.m.—“about ten hours before ‘Saturday in America’ comes to an end
column3: and any time between now and then
column4: our country could go up in flames. So as much as I appreciate your loyalty
column5: keep your eye on the prize. Got it?”"|"The President Is Missing"|"Bill Clinton"

column1: < 15:00|"nearly 3:00 p.m."|"I check my watch: nearly 3:00 p.m. The virus could go off any minute
column2: but no later than nine hours from now."|"The President Is Missing"|"Bill Clinton"

column1: 12:00|noon|"“Yes. Wednesday

column4: a logical place for people of our age to fit in and a fixed point we both could find.”"|"The President Is Missing"|"Bill Clinton"

07:23|"7:23 AM"|"In the communications room
column2: reading the text messages between Nina and our Benedict Arnold from Sunday
column3: May 6
column4: I now see how Lilly became involved. It was our insider’s way of getting Nina to access me directly without going through anyone else
column5: keeping the insider’s fingerprints off the whole thing. Nina’s reply:

column1: Nina (7:23 AM): You want me to tell the president’s daughter?

00:00|midnight|"“You’d know better than anyone how to get hold of Suliman. You’re the one who orchestrated that first call through our intermediaries in Turkey. You could’ve done it again. She told you everything
column2: Carrie. I read the rest of the text messages. She laid out her whole timeline. Augie
column3: the baseball stadium
column4: the midnight detonation of the virus. She trusted you. She trusted you
column6: and you killed her.”"|"The President Is Missing"|"Bill Clinton"

column1: 00:00|midnight|"But the people who brought him here won’t be waiting until midnight Eastern Standard Time to confirm the success or failure of the virus. Not if they’re reading the news."|"The President Is Missing"|"Bill Clinton"
